#Text=2. Model and Method
#Text=2.1. SIR Model for Contagion Propagation
#Text=In this work , we focus on an undirected graph , where V is the set of nodes and E is the set of edges .
#Text=Each node has its possible state — Susceptible ( S ) , Infected ( I ) , Recovered ( R ) .

#Text=The susceptible nodes represent the people who are infected easily but have not been infected yet , meanwhile the infected nodes denote the citizens who have already been infected and are capable of infecting other nodes .
#Text=The recovered nodes are the individuals who remain immune or die .
#Text=Suppose that there is a time-slotted system .
#Text=At first , only several nodes are infected , which are the contagion sources in the network .
#Text=Meanwhile , the other nodes are susceptible .

#Text=At each time step , each infected node infects its susceptible neighbors with probability p independently , that is , a susceptible node is infected with probability when it has n infected neighbors .
#Text=Meanwhile , the infected nodes turn to be recovered with probability q .
#Text=Additionally , the recovered nodes will not be infected , which may die or be removed .
#Text=2.2.
#Text=Problem Formulation
#Text=As a contagion propagates through a complex network under the SIR model , all the nodes will change infection state as time goes by .
#Text=The susceptible nodes may be infected by infected neighbour nodes and the infected nodes recover to a recovered node with a certain probability .

#Text=Due to the emergency response to contagion , we mainly consider an initial infection situation of the whole network and only collect two states , infected and uninfected ( susceptible , recovered ) , of all nodes .

#Text=Accordingly , the problem of the multiple sources localization problem can be described as — given the simple snapshot of the network at an early certain moment , how can we accurately locate multiple sources ?
#Text=It is common that we know the state of almost all nodes , but we have no ability to distinguish the susceptible nodes from the recovered nodes .
#Text=Therefore , all nodes can be divided into two states — infected and uninfected , which decreases the accuracy of multiple sources localization certainty .
#Text=2.3. Potential Concentration Label Definition
#Text=In the early period of severe contagion propagation , disease outbreaks through a crowd quickly .
#Text=It comes to the situation that the nodes around sources are more likely to be the infected nodes , that is , the sources are surrounded by many infected nodes .
#Text=Only by depending on the infection states can we locate the sources in a complex network accurately .
#Text=Inspired by
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=a , which shows the concentration of a pollutant , it is clear that the sources are more likely to be the node set , whose concentration is the highest ( 10 ) .

#Text=In fact , to get the state of each node is not easy , for example , some sensors do not have the capacity to measure concentrations , and can only judge whether the concentration surpasses a threshold value or not , and even then we may lose the concentration information .
#Text=Therefore , the information we can obtain is incomplete , just like in
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=b. We can see two concentration states easily , 0 or 1 ( 1 denotes concentration over 8 , 0 denotes concentration under 8 ) in a network , where an error occurred with node c .
#Text=It seems we have no ability to identify the sources according to these concentrations , which is similar to the infection situation of contagion .
#Text=Therefore , a new index needs to be proposed so as to distinguish between the sources and other nodes for incomplete pollutant diffusion and contagion propagation .
#Text=We think the node with more infected neighbors , including the first order neighbor , the second order neighbor and so forth , is closer to the sources .
#Text=Based on the above analysis , we propose a new concept , namely a potential concentration label , denoted by .
#Text=The potential concentration label is determined by its initial label and the labels of neighbor nodes .
#Text=The experiments demonstrate that it is a good index for locating multiple sources of contagion in complex networks under the SIR model .
#Text=2.4. The Method
#Text=In this section , we present the method at length in this section .
#Text=The purpose of is to locate multiple contagion sources , which is realized by following four steps in Algorithm 1 .
#Text=Step 1 : Label Assignment in the Snapshot of Network
#Text=Due to the incomplete information , only two states can be seen in the network — infected and uninfected ( susceptible and recovered ) .
#Text=The infection state of nodes is shown as follows — infected nodes carry the virus , denoted by 1 ; uninfected nodes carry no virus , denoted by 0 .
#Text=That is , if node i is infected , then ; if node i is uninfected , then , where is the initial potential concentration label of node i .
